On the morning of that eventful day, Saul had neared Damascus with feelings of self-satisfaction because of the confidence that had been placed in him by the chief priest. To 
                                                                           118
him had been entrusted grave responsibilities. He was commissioned to further the interests of the Jewish religion by checking, if possible, the spread of the new faith in Damascus.  He had determined that his mission should be crowned with success and had looked forward with eager anticipation to the experiences that he expected were before him.
